div.head: General
div.p: Darfur is a region in western Sudan comprised of the Sudanese provinces of North Darfur, South Darfur, West Darfur, East Darfur and Central Darfur. It gets its name from the largest non-Arab population group, the Fūr or Fōr. The poor and neglected region has been riddled with conflict since 2003.

Arabic is the language of prestige and the trade language for the whole Darfur region, despite many Darfurians having a mother tongue other than Arabic, mostly Nilo-Saharic languages. It is also the language of education in schools and Quranic schools (xalwa). The use of local languages is discouraged by the government. The prestige dialect is Khartoum Arabic. The dialect(s) of monolingual Arab Bedouins who are mainly cattle breeders (hence called baggāra) exist alongside Darfur colloquial Arabic spoken by the mostly illiterate and multilingual sedentary citizens of Darfur. The Arabic native speakers immigrated to the region through Fezzān in Libya and speak a ḥassāniyya-type dialect. Despite its many non-native speakers, Darfur Arabic shows no reduced morphology and therefore cannot be classified as a pidgin or creole language. It is often perceived as non-Arabic because phonological features considered typical for Arabic have been lost and/or changed, in particular the pharyngeals and emphatics.

div.head: Research history
div.p: Roset’s 2018 doctoral thesis is a grammar of Darfur Arabic that alongside an ample description also contrasts it with the Arabic dialects of Chad and the baggāra-dialects of Nigeria and the neighbouring Kordofan region. Roset 2015 looks at the phonology of Darfur Arabic. Behnstedt 2013 bases his conclusions on Interviews with Sudanese refugees. Isḥāq 2002 is a study in Arabic on the Darfurian dialect, complemented by the 2011 dictionary.

div.head: Dictionaries
div.p: An Arabic dictionary of the Darfur colloquial is Isḥāq 2011. Roth 1969 is an Arabic-French-English lexicon of the Chadian-Sudanese area.
